p: Since pathogens evolve over a transmission history, the analysis of pathogen genetic sequences taken from different hosts provides a way to infer the most likely donor and recipient [ 11] introducing constraints on the space of possible transmission trees, which are a trace of the underlying contact network. Phylodynamics [ 12] focuses on linking methods of phylogenetic analysis with epidemiological models under the assumption that if the evolution of a pathogen occurs sufficiently fast, transmission histories become “recorded” in the between-host pathogen phylogeny ( phylogenetic tree).
